terrain.surface: Gravel roads through WI countryside. Moderate elevation with countryside scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional WI event. Rolling terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Pickerel Buck40 is a regional event in Wisconsin—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The WI countryside is nice, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3. Wisconsin provides good access.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional WI gravel race with rolling terrain. Worth it for WI/Midwest cyclists seeking a shorter event. Not a destination race for national travelers.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in WI/Midwest and want a local shorter event—yes, it's solid. If you're from out of region—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For longer WI events: Bear 100, Hungry Bear 100. For similar regional events: other WI gravel races.

logistics.food: WI has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: WI rolling countryside requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Self-supported format with no course marking means "use paper cue sheets, gpx, or your phone to navigate." Shane Hitz calls this route "hard, no doubt about it" with gnarly chunk roads and unrelenting sand sections that vary by drought conditions.

length.explanation: 40 miles with a sub-10-hour benchmark and only two resupply options at Pickerel or Waubee Lodge. The route offers bikepacking as an alternative to the single-day format for Ironbear 1000 eligibility. More compact than Grinduro. As Shane Hitz puts it: "This route is hard, no doubt about it. It has two sections of old school singletrack the first being four miles long... It has about 20% roads that are gnarly chunk or unrelenting sand."

technicality.explanation: 33% pavement balances technical sections including four miles of old school singletrack and shouldering bikes over downed trees. Nick Holzem notes the steep ATV trails are "even harder at night despite trail repairs." Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 2500 feet over 40 miles includes climbs up Big Rock and Thunder Mountain. Nick Holzem describes pushing his full suspension rig up Big Rock then "had a blast riding down the steep technical chute." Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: June conditions bring "muddy two-track" and river ford crossings. Shane Hitz notes drought years worsen sand sections since "this area hasn't had meaningful rain since the beginning of May." Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Northern Wisconsin lowlands provide zero altitude training benefit. Heat management becomes the priority - Shane Hitz used "almost all of the four liters I was carrying on one section" during hot conditions. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: River ford at mile 28 and routes through "overgrown vegetation" to "remote and hard-to-get-to places." Wildlife encounters include Chris Schotz meeting "a fairly good sized bear at dusk" that left when confronted.

prestige.explanation: This is IRONBULL's Wisconsin deep cut that nobody outside the Midwest has heard of. No competitive timing, no pro field, no race reports floating around social media. It's part of the Ironbear 1000 challenge, which adds some credibility, but that's more about grinding through events than earning bragging rights.

race_quality.explanation: Free event with self-timing and flexible June window. No course marking or aid stations, just route curation through technical terrain that demands navigation skills and self-sufficiency planning.

experience.explanation: Route travels through Nicolet Trail and Butler Rock area with "loose big rock, and plenty of sand." Shane Hitz found renewal after a tough first day, describing magical night riding "with all of the fireflies."

community.explanation: Group departure option June 1st at 7am encourages social riding. Chris Schotz notes ATV riders on Nicolet Trail are "nice enough and always have a cooler" offering Miller Lite to passing cyclists.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, self-supported format attracts adventure seekers over competitive racers. Elite riders use it for training on longer IRONBULL routes, but the flexible timing window spreads out any potential field concentration. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Free gravel ride requiring only registration "to be included in the results." Access to northern Wisconsin's technical terrain and Ironbear 1000 eligibility without entry fees delivers solid adventure value.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-100. Remote Pickerel location limits lodging options, with Waubee Lodge serving as key resupply. Elite riders recommend 700x50 tires minimum for the technical sections, with some choosing full suspension setups. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
